title: sun readers salute britains bravest army tradesmen st john ambulance
story: Our Hail Your Heroes paper pullout, now in its seventh week, is the place where YOU have shone a light on the good deeds that are getting us through these dark times.Today we reveal a volunteer who spent his st birthday helping others – and military veterans beating PTSD by giving their all.Thanks to each of you named here. You are all amazing.If you want your message to be published FREE in The Sun on Sunday email sundayfeatures@the-sunWe’re proud of every one of you!I WOULD like to thank our amazing colleagues at CO-OP for going above and beyond to ensure communities continue to be supported, and to thank our members and customers for working with us during this uncertain time.Debbie Robinson, Chief Executive, Central England Co-op.I FEEL the BRITISH ARMY are unsung heroes of the fight against Covid-.Like the rest of the nation, I have unlimited respect for the NHS and the thousands of carers and essential workers who are doing amazing work to fight this terrible virus with selfless commitment. Every Thursday I go outside with the rest of the country to applaud.But the Army is left out of the heartfelt thanks that we, rightly, hear for other essential workers. The Army is working tirelessly, testing hundreds of thousands potential Covid- sufferers, with minimal PPE. Soldiers are working long hours, often having to self-isolate away from family.Joanne DaviesBURTON-ON-TRENT SCRUBBERS have been doing a fantastic job making scrubs for NHS staff in the local area.TINA ELLISON GRIST and a TEAM OF SEAMSTRESSES have been busy producing gowns. BILLY CLIFFE, alias Billy Fish, has been dressing up and running a home auction to raise money for the materials – more than £, has been raised to date. Tina and Billy are real heroes.DerekClfeWE would like to thank our son MARTIN HILTON, from Herne Bay, Kent, for doing all our shopping and keeping us both safe during the lockdown. Both he and his we are essential workers and we are very proud of them.Mum and DadTHANKS to all BOOTS STAFF for going to work during this pandemic, and especially to the Ryde High Street branch on the Isle of Wight. It’s been so manic, so physically and mentally draining.Pam GrovesWE would like to say a heartfelt thank you to our beautul daughter LISA WILSON, who works her -hour shts or longer every week in a private nursing home in Cardf. Lisa is a psychiatric nurse and knows the risks of her job but just shrugs her shoulders and says she is doing her bit like all the other frontline workers. As well as this, Lisa looks after her daughter, Jordane, and lives with her fiance Paul. Every Thursday we clap, while worrying for our own heroine Lisa.Rob and Janette WilsonFor kind-hearted chef Andrew spent it volunteering at Southend Hospital after he was put on furlough.But he says it was a birthday to remember as he has “the best volunteering job” overseeing a “kindness table” of donated food items.Every day generous people and businesses donate to it as a way of saying thanks to NHS staff – and Andrew and a team of volunteers are there to receive everything from chocolate to toiletries to distribute to heroic staff on the front line. Last week his kindness was also ed when staff brought him a surprise st birthday cake.Andrew, from Shoebury, Essex, says: “I was happy to volunteer on my st birthday as it’s such an amazing role.“I couldn’t believe it when I was presented with a cake. I was almost in tears when I saw they’d gone the extra mile for me.“ I absolutely love volunteering at the hospital, the people are just brilliant. It’s one of the best things I’ve ever done.“I see extraordinary kindness every day, from the staff helping people to those wanting to give something back to them.”Andrew began volunteering for the hospital last month after being furloughed from his job as a chef at the Stop the World café in Leigh.He says: “The hospital had put an ad out for volunteers. I applied straight away. I wasn’t scared at all about working in a hospital during the crisis. I was just keen to help.”As well as manning the “kindness table” Andrew has also been driving to collect donations. Hardworking NHS staff are able to choose items, like cakes and chocolate, during their much-needed breaks.He says: “It’s the small things that brighten up their day and I’m glad I’m able to be part of this.”This is not Andrew’s first time volunteering. He also works as a first-aider for St John Ambulance in his spare time.Andrew is so dedicated to helping others that he also missed out on his th birthday celebrations while helping St John Ambulance at the London Marathon. He says: “ I love helping others and get so much out of volunteering. When I get back to work I’m still hoping I can help out at the hospital, as it’s been such a great and fulfilling experience.”Voluntary services manager Jane O’Connell said: “Andrew has been a godsend. He is always available and always so cheerful.“Due to age, heath issues and lockdown, we had to do without  of our  volunteers last month.“We’ve been overwhelmed by the level of support and can’t thank all of them enough, including Andrew.”HUGS and kisses to SAMANTHA CONWAY and NICOLE PARKER and all the staff at THE EVERGREENS CARE HOME, Talbot Woods, Bournemouth, who do a fantastic job looking after the residents. Take lots of care and keep safe.Harry  DarcyI WOULD like to thank ZACH ALMOND, who is a paramedic and has not only been saving lives around the country and working so hard for the NHS, he has also been so kind posting on Facebook and offering to get groceries for the vulnerable anywhere in North London. He doesn’t rest. He is such a kind and caring friend.Jemma PrittieHOW about a big mention for our COMMUNITY CARERS visiting clients in their own homes. They are putting themselves on the frontline by being out and about every day. Well done and thank you.Jan WoodbridgePLEASE give a big shout-out to our decades-old friend CARER JULIE BRYANT, who is a carer in Plympton, Devon, and doing an amazing job with her colleagues. They are unsung heroes.Lizzie and Sarah I KNOW there are numerous people who deserve praise with regard to the Covid- battle, but there are two doctors who are on TV doing a grand job spelling out easy-to-understand advice. These doctors are Channel ’s DR SARAH JARVIS and ITV’s and The Sun’s DR HILARY JONES. Thanks so much to both of them, for all their invaluable help.N. Newton, RomfordON March , after helping an elderly gentleman who was struggling to find things he needed in the supermarket, SPALDING COVID KINDNESS TEAM was set up. There are now  committee members and around  volunteers. On Tuesday,  bulk fruit boxes went to care homes, schools and frontline workers,  care packages went out on Wednesday,  fresh fruit-and-veg bags were packed and  inidual requests for prescriptions and essential shopping were sorted on Thursday.The team deal with calls for emotional support and help people stay connected with distant relatives. They have taken a card and sung Happy Birthday to a -year-old lady whose family couldn’t visit her. And they are VOLUNTEERS, who give so much help to the vulnerable in Spalding and the surrounding area. So thank you.Bob WishartBORIS JOHNSON is back running the country and again lting the spirits of the people of the UK. Well done to Boris, and his MINISTERS AND EXPERTS, for all the hard work they have done and continue to do. Thank you.Cheryl LloydBilly MacLeod and his volunteers from Veterans In Action are collecting and distributing food across Hampshire — and demand is skyrocketing.Billy, , served as a corporal in the Royal Engineers until  and completed tours in Northern Ireland, Belize and Germany before suffering from PTSD.He said: “Until last week we had delivered more than , packages of essentials but this week the number of people we’re helping has doubled.“The deeper we get into this, the more the need is rising. We collected food generously donated for an extra , people last week. It went to everyone from the elderly self-isolating to school kids to ensure they get a decent meal inside them.“Every one of our team has mental-health issues as a result of their service. They are helping themselves by helping others. And we are all proud to do our bit to help Britain again.”The Hampshire charity normally organises foreign expeditions to help veterans with mental-health problems stay active. Billy said: “As soon as we knew coronavirus would cancel all our planned trips, I knew we could make a dference with our military backgrounds.“Every morning we head out to pick up the bags of food and household items donated by the public, then go through our list of requests. The mountain of goods donated every day makes your heart melt. It gives our volunteer veterans a sense of purpose while helping the community when they need us most. It’s win-win.”Each of the care packages is specically filled with items each family has requested, eventhey have dietary needs such as a nut allergy, or they are vegans.Bags typically contain a range of canned and dried foods, bathroom essentials such as deodorant, wipes and shampoo, and kitchen essentials such as cooking sauces. The team works with the local council and the Andover Isolation Help Group adds in a range of fresh fruit and veg.Keith Tucker has been volunteering with Veterans In Action since .He served in the   Lancers and left as a corporal in the early Eighties suffering from PTSD.“Going out and doing the collections has given me the focus to leave the past where it belongs — in the past. The VIA team is proud to help.”To mark VE Day, the team — which also includes Stephen Reilly, Duncan Crockett and Maurice Sweeney — gave out  care packages in the morning and another  in the afternoon.Billy added: “We’d planned a drive to Berlin to retrace the British Army’s steps in the lead-up to VE Day but the disappointmentvanished the moment we found this new calling.“When you see the look on the faces of these isolated people opening their doors to see a pile of bags filled with essential items, it really gives you perspective.“It’s an honour to be helping out in times like these.”We are so proud of our mammy, daughter and sister CARRIEANN CHAPPELL. She goes into work everyday as a creche worker to look after the children of other key workers, enabling them to stay on the frontline. She always keeps a massive smile on her face and makes sure everyone stays safe. She does all of this while homeschooling her own children and looking after other vulnerable family members and neighbours. We honestly couldn’t be prouder of you, keep up the good work!The Chappell ClanI WOULD like to thank KOPI KALANATHAN, a COSTCUTTER store owner who has gone the extra mile. Kopi and his team worked around the clock to bring forward the opening of his new shop because he knew local people were crying out for access to essential items during these challenging times. They are offering free deliveries for the vulnerable and NHS workers, as well as offering nurses, ambulance staff and police officers free coffee, breakfast and lunch. Kopi is also reserving essential stock for nursing homes.SophieMANY thanks to my husband KEVIN DAVIS for his constant help and perseverance. He works nights as an HGV driver delivering to supermarkets, and does all our shopping, including for my mum, who is  today and lives with us. I have diabetes so am on lockdown. Kevin also makes time to work on the garden and helps keep the housework under control. Love you lots.Julie DavisTHANKS to my husband PATRICK JONES, who moved from London to Northern Ireland with me to support my ageing parents John and Maeve. His support for my father, especially, has been amazing and during lockdown his kindness and sense of humour keep Dad’s spirits up. He also motivates Dad to stay mobile, which is key.Marie JonesA HUGE well done and thank you to Health Minister MATT HANCOCK and all the team involved in getting our testing capacity and delivery to the k daily target. I’m delighted that they’ve been able to show just how much can be done to help save lives. A huge well done, again.Mike ScottA No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.” SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking our readers to please sign the petition below.A BIG thank you to my son-in-law SIMON O’SHEA, my daughter CATHY O’SHEA and GRANDDAUGHTERS for their loving care and kindness, in these dficult times. They have kept me safe, well-fed and sane. In these sad, dark days of stre, they light up my le. British Hollywood stars, international pop superstars, the odd politician . . .  well, they’re history. title: sun on sunday hail your hero
story: THE Sun on Sunday has been applauded for journalism excellence for the Hail Your Hero campaign where you, our readers, say thanks to those who have stepped up during the pandemic.A  of expert judges from Press Gazette – the media industry’s bible - recognised it as one of “the best editorial innovations of the pandemic so far”.The campaign – now in its seventh week – has shone a light on unsung heroes and heroines from care workers, to members of the public making vital PPE from their homes and also volunteers distributing food and medical supplies to those who are self-isolating.Press Gazette said: “The pandemic has inspired some news businesses across the UK and beyond to find new ways of reporting and sharing news with readers and viewers.”The Sun was also recognised for its Who Cares Wins campaign which last week celebrated raising £ million towards care packages, food and vital equipment for brave nurses, doctors and NHS staff on the coronavirus frontline.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: 5 most common coronavirus myths
story: Advertorial most common coronavirus myths people are still falling forWith misinformation re – and dangerous – make sure you get the facts, not hoodsShareByDave Masters:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY Advertorial" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailEveryone’s looking for the latest information on health, and how to protect you and your family from the coronavirus in these uncertain times. But with misinformation re – and dangerous – itaposs important to make sure you get the facts, not hoods. Hoaxes and health scares add to peoples’ anxiety at a time like this, particularlythey’re vulnerable or elderly. From the rumour that G is causing Covid-, to the myth that sipping water every hour stops you catching it, misinformation is everywhere.Scams can pop up on your phone too, with fake texts supposedly from the Government, promising financial help or warning of a fine for breaking lockdown. Digital Secretary Oliver Dowdensaid: The need for trusted information about coronavirus is vital. The UK media is performing a key role in getting this to people. “Misleading claims about the virus online could cost lives and we are working around the clock with tech firms to tackle these. We can all do our bit by being sceptical about what we read online. I urge people to follow these steps to ensure they’re not inadvertently spreading dangerous hoods. Here weaposve debunked five of the most common myths to help keep people safe.And below you can also check out the SHARE checklist for advice on how to spot fake news. And rely on trusted sources, not rumours, to check facts. For advice on health, that’s nhs.uk. For government guidance on work and money, it’s gov.uk  Myth: “If you go outside more than once a day, a £ fine will be added to your mobile bill.”FACT: Although the Government has advised people to stay at home, you can go outside for food, health reasons or work . Your mobile company wouldn’t be collecting a fine.Myth: “If you’re entitled to free school meals, send your bank details to receive financial support.”FACT: This is fake and you never need to send your bank details via text or WhatsApp.  Myth: “Hot drinks can help flush the virus into your stomach, where the acid kills it.”FACT: This has been categorically disproved. Myth: “The Army is making a giant lasagne at Wembley and delivering it to every home via drone.”FACT: This joke did the rounds via WhatsApp, but sadly for pasta lovers it’s not true.  Myth: “Lidl are giving away a £ coupon for completing a short survey.”FACT: Fake! Beware of phishing messages sent via WhatApp. Always check a retailer’s main website rather than clicking a link. Before you share... SHARE  Think before you like, comment or share online and use the SHARE checklist to make sure you’re not contributing to the spread of harmful content about coronavirus. Source Rely on official sources for medical and safety information. Check the facts about the coronavirus on the NHS.UK website and GOV.UK.HeadlineHeadlines don’t always tell the full story. Always read to the end before you share articles on coronavirus.AnalyseAnalyse the facts. If something sounds unbelievable, it might very well be. Independent fact-checking services are correcting  information about the coronavirus every day.RetouchedWatch out for misleading pictures and videos in stories about coronavirus. They might be edited, or show an unrelated place or event. Check to see who  is using the photo.ErrorLook out for mistakes. Spelling and other errors might mean the information is . Official guidance about coronavirus will always have been checked carefully.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAll travellers into the UK may be forced to undergo a mandatory -day quarantine under new plans to stop a second peak of the coronavirus pandemic. Passengers arriving at airports and ports will have to provide an address at which they will immediately self-isolate for a fortnight, with the threat of a £, fine and even deportation enforcing the new rules. This could mean Brits will have to take one month offthey want to go on a two-week holiday - two weeks for a holiday, two weeks in quarantine at home afterwards. Thataposs sparked fears there will be no demand for holidays abroad this year and leading to calls for clarity from the tourism industry. The move is predicted by the Times to be announced by Prime Minister Boris Johnson in his address to the nation tomorrow, and the measure is expected to be implemented in June. The paper reports that authorities will conduct spot checks, with punishments for those not adhering to the rules including fines of up to £, and deportation. A Home Office spokeswoman said: We do not comment on leaks. The focus remains on staying at home to protect the NHS and save lives. The aviation industry is calling on the Government to reveal specics of the proposal amid concerns that the measures could have severe repercussions for the travel and tourism sectors. We need to see the details of what they are proposing, Airlines UK, which represents British Airways, EasyJet and other UK-based airlines, said in a statement. Airlines UK issued a statement saying the proposal would effectively kill international travel to and from UK and cause immeasurable damage to the aviation industry and wider UK economy. For the latest coronavirus updates, follow our liveblogIt added: Nobody is going to go on holidaytheyaposre not able to resume normal le for  days, and business travel would be severely restricted. It will also make it all but impossible for aviation to resume any time soon, thereby setting back the UKaposs economic recovery still further. Shadow foreign secretary Lisa Nandy told BBC Breakfast: Itaposs something that weaposve been asking ministers to clary for weeks now. I raised it with the minister for the fth time on Thursday because itaposs caused real confusion. At the moment weaposve got a lot of Britons who are still stranded abroad. People have been brought back in relatively large numbers and many of them are telling us that they have no information or advice given out about what they should be doing when they get home. They travel back from the airport on public transport, they go back to their families and theyaposre worried that theyaposre putting their families and other members of the public at risk, and some of them are coming from parts of the country where we are seeing an increase in infection rates, and so theyaposre really worried about it, the wider public are really worried about it, and for weeks weaposve had mixed messages being briefed out of government.  She added: I think thereaposs a real reluctance to do anything without official advice at the moment, so I donapost think the big problem is getting people to follow it. The big problem is actually getting that advice to people in the first place and itaposs been far too slow and far too confusing for most people. Thereaposs also a very real outstanding issue about the way in which people are being brought back into the country. A lot of the cases that Iaposm dealing with - my office is in touch with around , British nationals who are still stranded abroad - is about how they get to the airport on the other side of the border. People travelling across Spain, for example, on coaches, they get to the airport, itaposs very crowded, theyaposre being crammed onto planes without social distancing measures in place. Some of them are telling me thereaposs no hand gel available. Then, of course, thereaposs no testing facilities when they arrived back into the UK, so itaposs welcome that the Government has started to respond to this, but weaposve got to get much, much quicker at this or weaposre going to see a resurgence in cases.  The ISU union - which represents borders, immigration and customs staff - called for clarity on the quarantine plans. ISU professional officer Lucy Moreton told BBC Radio aposs Today programme: At the moment this is just a leak, so we havenapost had any particular information. Thereaposs a little bit of a discrepancy about whether this is airline passengers only or whether this is going to include iniduals arriving by boat. And what are we going to do with the irregular migrants who donapost have a private house to self-isolate in  Seemingly frustrated about no concrete information, she added: Iaposm hoping someone will get round to telling the staff at some point. She also questioned how it will be implemented, saying: Thereaposs no way for that e-gate to collect an address so weaposd have to do something, either shut those down completely or post staff either before or after to collect addresses. Airport Operators Associationchief executive Karen Dee said she has not received any details yet about a mandatory -day quarantine for all travellers into the UK. She told BBC Breakfast: I think thereaposs been lots of speculation in the press recently, and of course the transport secretary was on the Andrew Marr show last week, so although we havenapost had any details yet thereaposs been a lot of speculation that there will be a -day quarantine for passengers ing to the UK. That would have a really big impact on our sector, but at the moment we donapost have very much detail about what that would mean.  Ms Dee added: We see passenger numbers typically down by about % now in the UK. So, you know, a lot of airports now are closed for passenger traffic. There are very few flights coming in and that means no revenue, so weaposre really having to adjust and see our way through. The AOA chief executive said it was not known exactly what measures will be brought in for air travel. She told BBC Breakfast: Weaposre not medical experts and thataposs why weaposre keen to work with government and internationally to say what are the best things that we can do  Is it better cleaning and sanitation or hand sanitisers in the airport  Is it face masks and gloves for passengers to avoid touching  Is it some form of temperature checks at the airports or before they travel  Or other kind of testing that might evolve in the next few days or weeks  So at the moment, it could be a range of those options. She added: I think that there will be a range of things that passengers will see once we begin to scale back up, but at the moment I think itaposs really important that governments work with each other to say aposletaposs get one single international standardapos so that passengers know what theyaposre going to expect, wherever they are that theyaposre travellingapos.  It was put to Ms Dee that it would seem she has not had clear notication or clear guidance from the Government yet about what needs to be put in place. Asked what her impression is of not having had clarity, she told BBC Breakfast: I think the problem with that lack of clarity means that weaposre unable to plan. So, you know, itaposs perhaps not surprising that we donapost have that standard agreed, and we know that the Government is working now very closely, both with the industry and internationally, to look at what the science tells us we should do. So it is a problem as we begin to start and we will see some flights begin to take off, mostly repatriation at the moment of course, but I think it causes some confusion and what weaposre really keen to ensure is that those passengers that do begin to come back to us feel reassured, and also our staff. Tim Jeans, chairman of Cornwall Airport Newquay, warned of uncertainty for staff and businesses from reports of a -day quarantine for travellers entering the UK. He was generally critical of the Governmentaposs handling of borders, telling BBC Radio aposs Today programme: It was possibly inevitable but to say that itaposs come too late would be something of an understatement. He added that questioning the management and the planning of this is going to be very much at the forefront today. Now it does look that even though weaposre potentially past the peak weaposre going to close our borders and all the plans that airlines and airports had to start restarting operations are now on the scrapheap and will have to go back to square one, he continued.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailGarden centres reopening, travellers forced to self-quarantine, major changes to sht patterns and workplaces - just some of the many changes to our way of le as the lockdown is eased. On Sunday, Boris Johnson is set to reveal the Governmentaposs road map, setting out a plan on how restrictions will begin to be lted. Weaposve taken a look at eight sectors which will be affected by changes as the country begins to open back up. From our favourite fast food, to schools, workplaces and transport, here is what the initial stages could look like. International travel Travellers coming in to the UK could be expected to quarantine for  days after their arrival, reports suggest. Those visiting the UK will have to fill in a digital form and declare an address where they will then be expected to self-isolate for two weeks, according to The Times. For the latest coronavirus updates, follow our liveblog The paper reported that travellers from Ireland, the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man will be exempt from the quarantine. Briefing reporters on Friday, Downing Street confirmed quarantining foreign visitors was being looked at as a way of guarding the country against a second peak in the transmission rate. Passengers travelling through Manchester, Stansted and East Midlands airports are being ordered to cover their faces and wear gloves. Heathrow Airport has said it will introduce temperature screening, which will initially be used to monitor arriving passengers in immigration halls but could also be deployed in areas for departures, connections and airport staff searches. Shops Garden centres will be allowed to reopen to customers from Wednesday May , Boris Johnson will announce. Bosses will have to ensure shoppers obey social distancing measures, such as keeping two metres away from others, and will be expected to put restrictions in place, including queuing systems and installing Perspex shields to protect till staff. A senior Government source said: Garden centres are typically open large open-air spaces where the risk of transmission of coronavirus is lower. Last month, the British Retail Consortium published guidance for measures that retail stores could introduce to help with the transition once restrictions are lted, including limiting entry and exit points and using floor markings to outline social distancing. The workplace  Employees in non-essential industries who have been operating from home may be allowed toto work - but they might be encouraged to wear face masks and opt for a bike ride to avoid public transport where possible. Businesses wanting employees toto the office could be made to stagger shts, and ensure there are hand-washing facilities, hand gel and PPE supplies readily available. Boris Johnson will recommend workers wear masks when they doto work and when using public transport, The Dailyreported. Transport Secretary Grant Shapps is set to use his appearance at the Downing Street briefing on Saturday to unveil a further £ million for extra cycle lanes, while trials on the use of e-scooters on British roads are due to be fast-tracked, it is understood. Pubs and restaurants  Fast food franchises including McDonaldaposs and KFC have already announced they will begin opening locations for delivery services, with more sites likely to reopen in the coming weeks. Environment Secretary George Eustice said this week that drive-through restaurants such as McDonaldaposs are made for social distancing. The popular fast food chain has conducted trials on reopening stores, with  restaurants opening for deliveries from next week. Before reopening, the restaurants will be deep cleaned while new safety measures will be introduced such as Perspex screens and floor markings. The reopening of pubs and bars however is unlikely to happen any time soon, with some reports claiming they will notuntil August and September. Schools  Welsh First Minister Mark Drakeford said schools will not reopen in Wales in June. Mr Drakeford told BBC Radio aposs Today programme he expects Walesaposs very modest lockdown easing to be in line with what Boris Johnson will announce for England. Meanwhile unions sent a joint statement to Education Secretary Gavin Williamson on Friday, outlining a list of key measures which they say must be met before pupils in England can safelyto their desks. It includes extra money for deep cleaning and personal protective equipmentand local powers to close schoolsclusters of Covid- infections break out in a particular area. Exercise and the outdoors  According to some reports, unlimited outdoor exercise will be allowed from Monday, however gyms and playgrounds are expected to remain closed. Public Health England has signalled the stay home message could be abandoned and reports suggest people using benches, having picnics or sunbathing will no longer be asked to move on, provided they keep two metres apart. Public transport Bus and train timetables are likely to be adjusted and increased to help the system cope with an increase in passengers. There could also be further guidance on wearing masks while travelling after a survey by rail and road watchdog Transport Focus found % of people would not be happy using trains and buses unless passengers were required to wear them. It has been reported Boris Johnson will recommend workers wear masks when using public transport. He previously said face coverings will be useful when lockdown restrictions are eased.

It may also reduce the numbers of commuters on trains and buses, where the virus can easily spread. One minister reportedly told the : It makes complete sense. It would mean employees would not feel compelled toto the office and businesses may be able to limit the cost of alterations to workplaces, which would otherwise be necessary to enforce social distancing and prevent the spread of the virus. It is said the proposal, suggested by officials during discussions over the Governmentapossto work package, is being modelled on existing rules governing the rights of parents to request flexible working from their boss. Company bosses preparing to reopen offices shuttered are contemplating radical changes to the workplace to keep staff safe. Hand sanitisers and thermal scanners are just the start. Some firms are considering remodelling their offices to minimise the risk of a second wave of infections. Long rows of desks may be out, work stations sheathed with glass sneeze guards may be in.For the latest coronavirus updates, follow our liveblog Companies may be required to foot the bill for face masks for their staff whoto the office. A Government spokesman said: The Business Secretary continues to work with businesses, union leaders and the science and medical community so we can ensure workplaces are safe for those who will go back to work once the measures are relaxed and give people the confidence toto work. New research suggests almost half of workers believe they will spend less time in offices as a result of the coronavirus crisis. A survey of , workers found that almost one in two predicted a permanent change to their employersapos approach to flexible working when the lockdown lts.  Almost half of those surveyed by ICM for O said flexible working will increase, with a third expecting to increase the amount they work from home by at least three days a week. Many employees admitted the lack of social interaction was challenging, with a third saying working from home can be lonely, and one in four missing socialising with colleagues. Dr Heejung Chung, social policy director at the University of Kent, who is currently researching the impact of flexible working, said: It will be dficult to go back to normal ways of working after lockdown, as weaposve now proved that most of us can work from home, despite many companies previously telling employees that it wouldnapost be possible. Unions warn that many members are worried about being unable to practise social distancing should theyto work.  Last week, union bosses expressed fury at the governmentaposs back-to-work rules, branding them an open goal for rogue bosses. The TUCaposs general secretary Frances OaposGrady is understood to have urged ministers to strengthen their protections for workers with other union chiefs warning their members may refuse to workthey donapost feel safe. Department of Business officials are drawing up guidance to get people back to work in the coming weeks. Recommendations could include staggering sht times to ease the rush hour, avoiding hot-desking or sharing pens, closing lts and canteens.  But, although bosses are currently advised to keep workers two metres apart wherever possible, the guidance states: It will not always be possible to keep a distance of m. In these circumstances both employers and employees must do everything they can to reduce risk. Cabinet minister Ben Wallace signalled some firms will be allowed to adopt other measures, even halving the distance to one metreworkers are given screens and protective kit. He said: You could wear PPE, that could be a possibility, or indeed you could find other ways of doing it, shielding for example. Unions slammed the guidance - which only asks firms to consider the moves - insisting bosses should be forced to adopt them. TUC general secretary Frances OaposGrady said: Throughout this crisis the TUC has sought to engage constructively with ministers. But we cannot support the Governmentaposs back-to-work plans as they stand. They are an open goal for rogue employers, who will cut corners and put their workers, and the wider community, at risk.

title: saira kahn obey professor lockdowns

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMy best friend Jo is like a sister to me. We’ve been mates for  years and she knows me better than anyone. So to know she’s had the worst week of her le and I can’t be there for her is heartbreaking. And now I’m angry too. Jo’s dad was poorly. He collapsed at home and an ­ambulance came. He spent two weeks in hospital, on his own, with Jo taking him clean clothes, which she had to give to a nurse. The family knew they had to stick to the rules to protect others. Then I got the news from Jo. “Dad’s gone to sleep for good.” Hearing my soulmate go through the most painful experience of her le, I felt helpless and frustrated. I wanted to hug her, make her a cup of tea and look after things while she came to terms with a le without her hero in it. But I knew I couldn’t jump in my car and see her. Just like she had sacriced those precious final moments with her dad and couldn’t say goodbye. But you have to think of others and be a good citizen. Only, hang on, it’s okay to get your lover around for a quick bonk. Professor Neil Ferguson, the guy who instigated the lockdown and lectured the nation on social distancing, happily stuck two fingers up to his own rules. Inviting his married lover around was an “error of judgment” he said.  We’ve all been falling in line with this top scientist. When he says jump, most of us say how high – and with or without a face mask, Prof  We trusted his expertise. He was the smartest we had. So what a slap in the face to we ordinary folk when he decides it’s one rule for him and another for us. It’s a daily fear for many of us with elderly friends and relatives – them being taken to hospital, out of reach and left alone. For elderly people too, the thought of being left to die alone is too much to bear. And then the added trauma of funerals, when you can’t even say goodbye to loved ones properly.

title: calls oap homes nationalised virus
story: NewsCalls for care homes to be nationalised as virus pushes them to brink of collapseEXCLUSIVE: Covid- has claimed the lives of at least , residents as Tory peer Ros Altmann leads demands for radical change to prevent a catastropheShareCommentsByDan WarburtonAlan Selby:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsVoices from across politics are calling for social care to be nationalised " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailVoices from across the political spectrum are calling for social care to be nationalised as the Covid- crisis pushes our OAP homes to the brink of collapse. Tory peer Ros Altmann, a former ­pensions minister, is leading demands for radical change to prevent a catastrophe in the “financially unsustainable” sector. She warns looking after our , care home residents is now “a game of financial pass the parcel where hedge fund companies cash in on company debts”. And she adds bluntly: “Unfortunately, the parcels are old people’s lives – there’s nothing to stop them in this system.” Covid- has claimed the lives of at least , residents so far. Baroness Altmann told the Sunday People: “It’s possible we may need to nationalise the sector. We ­cannot let these companies go bust. “They are heavily loaded with debt and unless owners are willing to put equity in – which they haven’t been – they are not financially sustainable. “This is not new and there has never been proper control over financial backing for homes. With Covid-, the sector has come crashing down because it’s not ­integrated into the health service.“The coronavirus crisis in care homes is a continuation of the broken system that has been getting worse for years. What this has done is created a disaster for the most frail and vulnerable in our society.“Their needs have not been taken with the same seriousness as the needs of the NHS. A service and NHS system has been prioritised over these people’s lives. “The idea of freeing up capacity in the NHS – sending infected older people back to care homes where the staff didn’t have enough PPE and other residents could catch it – doesn’t bear thinking about. But that is what has happened.  “It brings me to tears to think of these elderly relying on our system, at the mercy of the crisis. We’ve protected the NHS as our totemic system while social care needs have been pushed aside. Care has always been the Cinderella part of our system.” Baroness Altmann said taxpayers must foot the bill for integrating health and care – a call echoed by Labour’s former Health Secretary Andy Burnham. Writing in the New Statesman ­yesterday, Mr Burnham, now Mayor of Greater Manchester, said social care has more in common with ­insurance-led US healthcare than “British values of fairness” ­embodied by the NHS. He said: “In , I proposed a National Care Service. The problem is it would still maintain two separate systems when they need to be one.  “Now I favour social care provided on NHS terms as part of a single, fully-integrated system.” Shadow Health Secretary Jonathan Ashworth said: “Our care sector is highly vulnerable and many homes are run by offshore companies. “We need social care to be put on a ­sustainable footing for the future – which is why Labour has talked about a National Care Service.”Labour pledged a National Care Service in the  election, and Boris Johnson vowed to deliver a plan to “fix the crisis” within  days of him becoming PM. That ­deadline passed in mid-March.In ,  per cent of ­residential and nursing home beds were provided by local authorities or the NHS. By  it was six per cent. Councils still covered  per cent of home care from visiting staff in  – but by  this was down to  per cent.  Critics say that since then, austerity has let private providers flood the sector. While local authorities pay a flat rate for beds for those who cannot afford care, private operators charge their own rates. For-profit companies now own ,, or . per cent, of England’s , care home beds, the IPPR think-tank found – up from  per cent in .  Labour previously pledged £.billion to buy care homes and build new ones, plus £.billion a year to run the sector. In the short-term, Baroness Altmann thinks Government bailouts may be needed, while Mr Burnham said the state should retain  per cent of a deceased person’s estate to fund care. In the longer-term, Mr Burnham believes funding should be absorbed into ­general taxation.

story: NewsDoctors despair as boozy bank holiday injuries swamp AE despite lockdownA doctor at Manchesters North West hospital said the AE was heaving with drunken patients with alcohol-related injuries when medics should have been focused on Covid- casesShareCommentsByAlexandra Rucki:,  MAY NewsThe doctor warned of chaos in hospitals already busy trying to deal with the Covid- pandemic " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAn exasperated AE doctor has described chaotic scenes in hospital as the bank holiday weekend got off to a boozy start in lockdown. The Manchester doctor said drink-related incidents and violence spiked on Friday night as patients appearing to have been injured defying lockdown landed in the emergency department.Dr Ben Stewart said his team were shocked at the numbers of people requiring treatment last night and well into the early hours of this morning, reports the Manchester Evening News.He described chaotic scenes during his . hour sht, with many patients being taken to hospital for alcohol or drug related injuries.The doctor said AE had been noticeably quieter since the UKaposs lockdown was introduced, due to people avoiding hospitals because of coronavirus and less people going out drinking.But that changed last night as the long weekend kicked off with a scorching start and Brits flocked outdoors. Follow our live blog for the latest coronavirus news and updatesThe docotor said it was back to the apospre-lockdown daysapos and it appeared a lot of people had become relaxed about the restroctions. He said: The number of alcohol or drug related accidents, violence and crime rocketed last night. The police we saw said it had been their busiest night since New Year’s Eve . We knew it was going to be busier than normal. Bank Holidays are always busier. The NHS for the last four or five weeks in AE, it became a lot more quiet.  We thought we would see a bit of a peak, but it was just a shock to everybody really. The doctor said people were attending for drink-driving injuries, cars flipping over, assaults and even violent stabbings. He said there were still patients coming in with Covid- symptoms, but the majority were for drink related incidents and had attended alongside the police. Dr Stewart said: You are celebrating defeating a big enemy, but we are back in the same situation now. We need to be sensible, but people have got relaxed about it. I saw  or  patients last night, two had Covid-, one had a headache, the rest were assaults or car accidents.  All kinds of unnecessary incidents. I am hoping everybody will wake up with a bit of a hangover today and today will be better. But it is a long weekend, with a Saturday included, and I am preparing myself for the worst. It is definitely back to the pre-lockdown days. We had seen a drop in footfall with people coming in, which is good as people who are genuinely sick are getting seen at the door. People forget that we still have people coming in with coronavirus. They are taking up a lot of our resources. But it has gone back to the good old days of everyone getting drunk and relying on AE. I think in the North West we have surpassed London. We knew we would trail behind them, we have probably just peaked.  You donapost climb Everest and open few cans of beer at the top, you donapost stop until you are back at base camp. People can have a good time, but we are not through everything yet. There is still a potential second wave particularly in the North West. The doctors comments come after up to  people were seen meeting to drink champagne in Salford Quays. It is a fabulous property but an acquired taste, Powsney said. Guys love it, but the women not so much. It has been a fantastic experience and I have learned a lot, but it is time to move on. I am  now. I was not a Fred fan at first, but the place is like the house in The Shining. It takes over you, it is a wonderful place steeped in history. The building known locally as aposTwo Catsapos is set in woodland on the banks of the River Tonge, not far from Bolton town centre. Mr Powsney purchased the Grade II-listed property for £, in , after it had failed to sell at auction. We originally intended to move to Spain, Mr Powsney explained. We sold our house but the credit crunch came so we bought that instead. I had no intention of turning it into a business, but we had that many people wanting to look around.He turned the property into the Fred Dibnah Heritage Centre, which soon became a site of pilgrimage for fans of one of Boltonaposs most famous sons. The spot the ball competition was dreadful. For a tenner, someone could have owned it with no mortgage. It could have given someone the chance to get on the housing ladder, he said. The house was then put up for auction last September with a guide price of £,, but failed to sell again.In a fresh attempt to find a buyer, the home is now being marketed by Hunters estate agents for £,. While Powsney says he would be willing to sell to whoever meets the asking price, he believes it would be ideal for one of Boltonaposs Menaposs Shed groups. For those who must travel to work, enabling more people to walk and cycle will be critical.” And David Renard, of the Local Government Association, added: “This new way of travelling is likely to become part of everyday le once the coronavirus measures are lted and beyond.” But Shadow Green Transport Minister Kerry McCarthy said: “We need a comprehensive plan to get our public transport moving again especially for those that can’t cycle to work.” Mr Shapps was asked by the Sunday Mirror how parents could cycle to work for the day before schools were fully up and running and wrap-around childcare such as breakfast and after-school clubs were available.

The home of Kevin Halligen, , was said to have been “bloodied” when he was found there on January , . Police at first treated his death as “unexplained” but coroner Richard Travers heard he died from a brain haemorrhage and that detectives found “no suspicious circumstances”. Despite being a convicted conman, the inquest recorded Mr Halligen as an “intelligence and security officer”. He ran Oakley International, which received £, of publicly donated cash after Madeleine vanished from Praia da Luz in Portugal aged three in . Halligen later denied claims the cash was siphoned off to pay for first-class travel, top hotels and a chauffeur. Paramedics called to Mr Halligen’s home in Normandy, Surrey, performed CPR on him but he could not be saved. A postmortem found he died of an acute subdural haemorrhage.  A pathologist testied at Woking coroner’s court last week that there was “no sign of an assault”. His death was reported to the coroner under the name of Richard Powell. Recording a verdict of accidental death, coroner Richard Travers said: “Mr Powell suffered a fall at his home address... and an ambulance was called.  “Despite attempts to save his le Mr Powell died at : hours that same day. “Police attended and found no suspicious circumstances and the postmortem examination did not reveal injuries consistent with an assault or third-party involvement.”

title: mark steel british governments clear
story: NewsopinionMark Steel: British governments clear advice on lockdown is not that clearWe shouldnt be surprisednext there is a live TV game show where celebs guess new lockdown rules while taking part in an obstacle course, hosted by Davina McCall, writes Mark SteelShareCommentsByMark Steel:,  MAY NewsopinionDavina McCall, potential host of a live TV show where celebs guess new lockdown rules " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailSome governments around the world give clear advice as to what their population should do next, such as “Stay indoors for two more weeks”. But that’s boring. We’re lucky, because our government is much more fun. First they told us: “Changes will be introduced from Monday.” So one Conservative newspaper announced: “Hurrah! Lockdown freedom beckons.” Then they changed their mind and said nothing can change, then that there would be some change but they wouldn’t let on what it was. Next week they’ll make it a fun game where we have to guess the change. We could try going to the beach, thenwe get tear-gassed by armed police, we’ll know it isn’t that. Or there could be a  game live on BBC in which a group of ­celebrities tries to guess the new rules by asking a series of questions while clambering round an obstacle course. Eventually Davina McCall will ask “are we allowed to drink cider with our mates at a bus shelter ”, while ­clambering up a slippery ladder, then Matt Hancock will ring a bell and we’ll know that’s the new rule. With a similar spirit, when Boris Johnson was asked whether we should wear face masks, he said they “might help”. That’s the sort of clear decisive instruction we expect from a leader in a crisis. His hero Churchill was the same, when the Germans tried to invade he said: “I suppose sending some Spitfires up against them might help. I’m not sure really, it’s up to you.” At one point there was a report that schools could be reopened on May , or maybe not. This is ideal, because le is dull when you go somewhere and know for certain itaposs open. This way, parents can take their kids to school and have the excitement of not knowing whether they’ll take them in for lessons, or all get arrested for being outside at a school gate.  This follows the Prime Minister’s earlier clear guidelines, when he said he would absolutely definitely visit his mother on Mother’s Day. He was then equally clear four days later he definitely wouldn’t see his mother on Mother’s Day. But each time he was clear so that’s the main thing. It might make more sensethe next statement is written by the Dalai Lama, and says: “You may travel round a bend, but your heart must take you in a straight line, for the playground in the park is the seesaw of your soul.”

story: NewsMiracle baby born one day after mum told she tested positive for coronavirusEXCLUSIVE Yumi Palmer fell ill with flu-like symptoms and lost her sense of smell -hours before a long, traumatic, labour to welcome her baby boyShareCommentsByMatthew Barbour:,  MAY NewsYumi Palmer called  after suffering flu-like symptoms and was told to self-isolate" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A new mum is counting her blessings with a healthy baby in her arms – after she was told she had coronavirus the day before her due date.Yumi Palmer was  hours from her first birth when she went down with flu-like symptoms and lost her sense of smell. A desperate call to  confirmed her worst fears. She was told she almost certainly had Covid- and must self-isolate with husband Matt until her labour began. Yumi, , then spent eight terrying days fearing her baby would be born with the disease before being rushed to hospital when her waters broke. But after a traumatic -hour labour and a birth in which she suffered serious bleeding, she is now back home with Matt and healthy son Ori – and has tested negative for the virus. “We’re counting our blessings every minute of every day,” says Yumi. “To be home with my husband and our beautul boy, all of us healthy, is all we need.” The couple had announced the pregnancy as a surprise to their wedding guests in August last year. Yumi, of Coulsdon, Surrey, got a due date of March  and had a smooth pregnancy. But with Covid- beginning to spread in the UK in early March, she and Matt began to worry when she started feeling like she had flu. Then losing her sense of smell, a coronavirus symptom, panicked them both. “I called my midwe, who told me to call  straight away,” she says. “ I explained my symptoms and was told I had coronavirus and had to self-isolate for  days.  “But this was one day before I was due to give birth.” Her waters broke on March . The couple rushed to Croydon Hospital, South London, but were sent home for the labour to progress before Yumi was finally admitted, but not without more drama. “I was in full labour and needed midwives, but because of all the PPE and other red tape they couldn’t get to me for ages – it was all so incredibly anxious.” Ori was born on March  weighing lbs oz – but he had barely been laid on his mum’s chest before she began to bleed badly and was rushed to surgery, for emergency stitches. Meanwhile Ori was given antibiotics to ward off a suspected infection.

Simone - who was a close friend of Dianaaposs until her death in  - says the Princess fears her younger son faces disaster after deciding to step back from the royal family with his we Meghan Markle earlier this year.In her letter to William, she wrote: Diana made me promise to keep an eye on both you and Harry to make sure you’re both OK, and to give you warnings of danger signs. I am writing, actually I’m begging you, to listen because Meghan will isolate Harry, and eventually cause him to attempt radical, possibly lethal, ­self-destructive actions. If you want to respond, feel free. We MUST save Harry. The healer says she used to chat to Diana for up to  hours at a time on the phone when she was still alive and that she now makes regular appearances at her London home. Diana comes and talks to me – I see her body and she’s very animated at times. I got so fed up of it all I wrote to William, but he hasn’t responded, Simone explains. “It’s going from bad to worse. “Harry’s been separated from everything he loves – his family and his friends, including the Army boys he loved. “Diana told me Harry is feeling more and more isolated and it’s like torture for him. “Diana told me it was all going to end in disaster. Simone, who met Diana in  at the Hale Clinic in west London, warned that something was going to happen to her that would be the death of her before her death in a car crash in Paris. The psychic also predicted that Meghan was pregnant with the coupleaposs son Archie before the news was formally announced. She has previously also written to Harry, before his wedding. She added: I’m going to write one more letter to him, but I’m told he and William refuse to read correspondence from their mother’s friends because they have been told we are not to be trusted. It’s so sad as it’s the only way they will get to hear the full truth about their mother.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAnti-racism campaigners have staged a protest over police use of a Taser on a man in front of his distressed child. A group of up to  people observed Covid- social distancing rules as they gathered at a petrol station forecourt in Stretford, Manchester, where the incident took place. Mobile phone footage widely shared on social media showed an altercation on Wednesday night between a black man and two white police officers. The man is seen standing next to a marked police car and puts down his crying son before moments later he falls to the ground as a Taser is fired by one of the officers. The boy then becomes hysterical and screams daddy. Mayor of Greater Manchester Andy Burnham has questioned whether the Taser use was proportionate or justied and has demanded an urgent review.Greater Manchester Police has voluntarily referred the matter to the Independence Office for Police Conduct . Among the protesters at the event staged by Stand Up to Racism on Saturday were Paul Davidson, a minister at the Church of God of Prophecy.  He said: I am here because this news has outraged black people nationally. We are obviously keen to find out what the details are and whether there are other circumstances we havenapost learned from the immediate clip. Butthe immediate clip is anything to go by then people have questions to answer and we should expect answers as a community. This sort of behaviour should not be expected by anyone in a civilised society.  The man who was hit with the Taser, Desmond Ziggy Mombeyarara, , appeared before magistrates on Friday where he admitted a number of offences including speeding, drink driving, failing to stop and unnecessary travel. He denied two counts of resisting a constable in the execution of their duty and the case was adjourned to a later date. In an interview with The Times, Mr Mombeyara said he did not believe such a magnitude of force was warranted.He said his son was still in shock and thought that police had shot him. He told the newspaper: I was saying to the officers, aposLet us calm the situation for the little one because the little one doesnapost feel comfortableapos. But they were making out like I was using him as a human shield. The scene was caught on camera by an eyewitness.GMP said the incident has been reviewed by the GMP Professional Standards Branch and that they have voluntarily referred this matter to the Independent Office for Police Conduct . Superintendent Mark Kenny, commented: We are aware of public concern regarding this arrest and I want to reassure the public that this matter is being reviewed and treated seriously.In addition we have voluntarily referred this matter to the IOPC.  Mayor of Greater Manchester Andy Burnham has issued a statement. He said: On Friday morning , a video was brought to my attention of a police incident at a petrol station in Greater Manchester involving two police officers, a man, a child and the use of a taser. . I was concerned about what I saw and immediately asked GMP to look into it and provide me with an explanation of what had happened.

title: voice mirror deserve honesty covid
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: We deserve honesty on Covid- not political liesBoris Johnson and his ministers have spun Britons lies, more damned lies and dodgy statistics since the coronavirus hitShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsopinionBoris Johnsons pledge of , Covid- tests wont be believed " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIt is a tribute to the fortitude and patience of the British people that nearly nine in  obey lockdown rules to the letter. The least we deserve infrom Boris Johnson and his ministers is transparency and honesty. What we get are lies, damned lies and dodgy statistics. A political lie is the willingness to deceive. Matt Hancock promised , tests a day by the end of April. When the th arrived, the Health Secretary simply mailed out an extra , to meet his figure. It was the Covid- equivalent of a cheque in the post. And he has missed his target six days in a row. So the nation will have little confidence in Mr Johnson’s pledge of , by the end of this month. A political lie is the failure to tell the unnished truth. Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick boasted of , surgical gowns from Turkey. They did not arrive next day as promised. When they did they were useless – a fact revealed by a newspaper, not the Government. A political lie is to claim there was enough PPE –and that became a damn lie as the lack of it costs lives. We are heading towards  frontline deaths. Claims that shortages were down to distribution dficulties were branded by the Enfield council leader Nesil Caliskan as “an absolute lie”. On becoming PM, Mr Johnson pledged to begin work immediately “to fix the crisis in social care once and for all”. Had he been telling the truth, care homes would not be in the desperate state they are now.  It was American writer Mark Twain who popularised the phrase “lies, damned lies and statistics”. His point was that numbers can be manipulated. No government is immune. Labour claimed it hit targets for patients to spend no longer than four hours in AE. But they were simply put in other parts of the hospital before time was up. The Tories reduced hospital waiting lists by not putting people on them. No’s daily graphs are today’s version of this sleight of hand. At first they appeared to show Covid- deaths on a similar trajectory as those in Italy, France and Spain. Only pressure to include victims outside hospitals revealed the true gruesome picture. If ministers had been straight with us we’d have known earlier we were heading for Europe’s highest toll. The statistics we do believe are of the sort compiled by the British Medical Association which show , doctors reporting no eye protection,  with no scrubs,  with no goggles and  without gloves.

title: dundee fc james mcpake transfers
story: James McPake has assured fans Dundee will be ready to hit the ground running after the coronavirus shutdown but admits the club “cannot go out and offer someone a three-year deal at the moment”.The Dens Park gaffer says he’s doing everything he can to prepare for next season, whenever it might start, despite the entire playing staff being put on furlough leave.With no indication yet when football will restart, clubs are understandably not in a position to sign new players – McPake, though, says he’s doing all he can to be ready for when the transfer market kicks back into le.The Dens gaffer said: “It has been an ongoing process since last summer.“We certainly cannot go out and offer someone a three-year deal at the moment.“But what is never going to stop or change is that we firmly believe we have a process in place for recruitment.“It has to get better but the fundamentals of what we do won#t change.“We have been working on this since last summer with regards to the January transfer window and then this summer’s transfer window.“So it is still ongoing. Hopefully, when the time#s right and everybody is safe, we need to make sure we are ready to go.”Dundee have been heavily linked with afor striker Simon Murray, who is a free agent after leaving South African side Bidvest Wits last month, while a permanent move for St Johnstone midfielder Ross Callachan could also be on the cards.His loan spell at Dens was ended prematurely with a broken leg but impressed in his short time there and is out of contract in the summer.McPake has also never hidden his desire to see Hearts forward Craig Wighton back with the Dark Blues.The current concern for teams like Dundee in the lower isions, however, is how next campaign might look.The SPFL have begun a league reconstruction task force led by Hearts chair Ann Budge and Hamilton chief Les Gray to revamp the setup for the new campaign.Dens Park managing director John Nelms is part of the -strong reconstruction group but McPake admits he’ll be happy with whatever future is decided, as long as it benefits the game as a whole.He added: “My preferred option is that we just find a way to get something that works.“Look, we need to make sure everything is safe first.“Do I have a preferred option  I would love to be in the Premiership but we had a chance to do that ourselves this season and we failed.“If we had won the league, it would have been a given.“Butreconstruction happens, whatever way, I just hope they do it so that it suits the game going forward.“Would our input as managers help  But do we then ask players as well “It is a tough one. Do I want to be involved  No, I am happy to leave it to the powers-that-be and just concentrate on my job getting our squad ready so that when we do get the green light to go ahead we can do that.“I just want football back, I think society wants football back andreconstruction comes in then great.“But there are people out there risking their lives to save lives so they are the real important ones.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

title: aberdeen woman spreads lockdown joy with outdoor zumba classes
story: An Aberdeen woman is spreading cheer during lockdown by holding Zumba classes in the streets in her community.Gillian Low, , normally holds sessions at Kingswells Public Hall and the local community centre – but those were put on hold as a result of Covid-.She has instead been holding the regular classes by video call.But to ensure people can still come together and enjoy the activity, Gillian also decided to take to the streets of Kingswells, holding socially-distanced Zumba Gold sessions for over-s, as well as traditional Zumba.And she believes the activity is providing the community with some much-needed enjoyment during the lockdown, while also helping them stay active and healthy.Come and join our live virtual Zumba class in your living room every WednesdayJust private message me for more information and the ZOOM link .We also have our virtual Zumba Gold class at pm too so all welcome.It#s still free todayso why not give it a go I#d loveyou can join us xxxPosted by Reiki and Zumba with Gillian on Wednesday,  April Gillian said: “As a Zumba instructor, I know how our classes make people smile, have fun and forget they’re exercising.“I thought it would be good to get folks of all ages out on the street in the nice weather, socially-distanced of course.“They’re with their neighbours, dancing, singing and enjoying themselves outdoors during the current Covid- restrictions.“Sunshine, fresh air and connection are, of course, great for the immune system and our state of mind.”She added: “I’ve done about six sessions so far in a few streets and I’ve been delighted with the turnout each time.  There have now been some requests for Street Zumba in other parts of the community so this is currently being organised to bring it to more people.”Gillian has been motivated to extend her classes to other parts of the community by the feedback she has received from those taking part.Kingswells residents aged up to  have participated in the classes, which can be done sitting down by those less able.Gillian is also holding virtual classes over Zoom to meet demand – and hopes Street Zumba can remain a regular fixture after lockdown measures have been lted.She said: “I must admit I hadn’t realised just how much this would benefit people but the participants have said how much they’ve been looking forward to the sessions, that ‘it’s lovely to see their neighbours with smiling faces’ and ‘seeing all neighbours together gives a really warm community feel’.“Even when Judy Laing, our local photographer, posted her photos and a note on Facebook on the community pages, we’ve had an incredible response from people saying it was ‘amazing’ and ‘the best thing they’d seen all day’.“I’ve started to make it a ‘Pay it Forward’ event so whilst I’m showing the participants kindness by providing the session, they then undertake to show kindness to someone , the community or the planet.  The ripple of kindness then spreads out and that inspires me to keep going.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

story: A popular north-east chef is running live cooking classes on Facebook during lockdown.Craig Wilson, known as the Kilted Chef, is running the show, Live at Five, three times a week on Monday, Wednesdays and Fridays.It aims to show people how they can get the most out of standard ingredients they#re likely to have at home, so people don#t need to go out and buy things specially.And the show also incorporates as much locally produced ingredients as possible.Episode  Live #  VE Day Fri th MayPosted by Eat On The Green on Friday,  May Craig, who is the chef and proprietor of Eat on the Green at Udny Green, said: #It#s almost like food up-cycling.“It’s about giving people ideas so they don’t have to think ‘I’m going to make something, I need this’.“If you’ve got half a cucumber and a little bit of tomato, a jar of chutney, how can you get the absolute most out of them.#Really, for me, you can be weird and wonderful with some of your combinations.#You#d be amazed, when you are as creative as possible, how you can come up with something really tasty.#Craig started the show five weeks ago and it has been a big hit, with around , viewers per episode.To watch the shows, visit facebook Kiltedchefcraig For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsLochgilphead Soccer Centre volunteers have received vital first aid training.Sports clubs are required to ensure a number of their volunteers have a valid first aid certicate and when Lochgilphead Soccer Centre looked to secure the services of an accredited firm to provide the required two-day course, outdoor and first aid coach Andy Craven was happy to help.Covering theory and practice of all fundamental aspects of first aid, the volunteers were grateful to Andy for his informative and interactive approach to learning important skills and knowledge to safeguard the welfare of players and spectators.Soccer Centre chairman Stuart Green  said: #It is not just about having the relevant certicate, but ensuring a good number of our volunteers have the knowledge, skills and equipment to look after our youngsters and their friends and families.#Knocks and sprains are common in football and we deal with them every week, however, even as volunteers, we have an obligation to be prepared with any eventuality and Andy was first class in guiding our volunteers through a range of scenarios.#Andy said: #Whilst first aid is a serious business, the folks at Lochgilphed Soccer Centre were a great bunch. They were keen to learn and kept me on my toes with a range of questions.#I am a qualied outdoor and first aid instructor and have been working with community and sports groups throughout Argyll and Bute and their enthusiasm and desire to develop skills to look after members of their community in the event of something going wrong never ceases to impress me. title: argyll sport decimated amid coronavirus response
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThe coronavirus response has forced the cancellation of sporting events up and down the region.Just when the situation will settle down enough to allow sport to re-start is anyone#s guess at this stage, but early casualties have included shinty, football, athletics and a planned youth football trip to Europe.The committee of Mid Argyll Athletic Club took the dficult decision to postpone the Argyll final of Sports Hall Athletics which was due to take place at Atlantis Leisure in Oban this Sunday, March .With more than  young boys and girls qualying for the final from the four local area competitions and the possibility of another -plus family member spectators filling the games hall the organisers felt it was sensible to postpone the event.A statement from the organisers said: #After consultation with the management staff at Atlantis Leisure it was decided it was best to follow the guidance that is currently being issued by the Scottish Government and others to attempt to restrict the spread of the coronavirus.#We will revisit a date for holding the competition once the coronavirus situation is clear andnecessary this may be have to be after the summer school holidays. The boys and girls who qualied from the local area competitions in Lochgilphead, Oban, Tobermory and Campbeltown will be advised of the new Argyll final date and times through their local club or school.#We apologise for any inconvenience and disappointment this postponement may cause to the young athletes and their families.#The annual Crinan Puffer # an .-mile race between Crinan and Ardrishaig # has also been postponed.A fundraiser for Mid Argyll Community Pool organised with the help of Mid Argyll Athletic Club, the run was due to be held on Sunday March .Announcing the postponement, Kirsty Young of Mid Argyll Community Pool said: #In light of current government guidelines to avoid non-essential contact and unnecessary travel we feel that this is the right decision to make.#I will be contacting all stakeholders involved with the organisation and running of the event in the coming days to try and come up with a date to re-schedule the event.#Months of work to raise money for a trip to Holland in April for young Mid Argyll footballers has come to nothing, thanks to coronavirus.Lochgilphead Red Star  players, coaches, parents and supporters were left disappointed when the Amsterdam tournament was cancelled.A committee spokesperson said: #The team are devastated not to be going after nine months of fundraising for the event. We are lucky enough to be getting a full refund from the organisers and at present are awaiting to seethe same will happen regarding the flights.#We would like to take this opportunity to thank everyone from the public to businesses who have supported us throughout our fundraising, from attending coffee mornings, donating at bag packs and online donations and our hypnotist night. Your generosity has been overwhelming .#We plan to let the kids of the team decide which charities they would like to donate the funds to once we receive the refund.#After just one week of the  season, shinty#s governing body, the Camanachd Association, made the decision on Friday March  to postpone all matches until further notice.The association also recommended that this should include all training, festivals and other events.In a statement, the Camanachd Association said: #In light of the government restrictions on public gatherings and the resulting pressure on emergency services and healthcare provision, the Camanachd Association has postponed all fixtures under our auspices whilst a further assessment can be made and to reduce any additional pressure our activities may have otherwise had on emergency services.#The wellbeing of the people in our communities is primary in this decision and we hope that this decision removes any expectations or pressures on participating during a time that we can be focused on doing all we can to suppress the spread of the virus.#The recommendation is that shinty clubs should hold any meetings using remote technology such as Skype.The
